p: Analysis of polling and public opinion shows that the most popular way to frame climate policy is in an intersectional manner that centers equity, justice, and the creation of jobs. Polling conducted in the US by Data for Progress, where I work, shows that a majority of voters support climate policy that incorporates clean infrastructures, creates millions of jobs, and jobs and disportionately invests in frontline communities. Furthermore, 56% of voters say they are more likely to support a presidential candidate that commits to transitioning America to 100% renewable energy by 2035.
